{{redirect|Königsberg question|the mathematical problem|Seven Bridges of Königsberg}} [[File:Kaliningrad Oblast within Europe.svg|thumb|right|Location of [[Kaliningrad Oblast]]]] The '''Kaliningrad question''' is a [[political]] question concerning the status of [[Kaliningrad Oblast]] as an [[exclave]] of Russia,<ref name="sebentsov">{{cite journal|last1=Richard|first1=Yann|last2=Sebentsov|first2=Alexander|last3=Zotova|first3=Maria|title=The Russian exclave of Kaliningrad. Challenges and limits of its integration in the Baltic region|journal=Cybergeo|date=8 April 2015|doi=10.4000/cybergeo.26945|url=https://journals.openedition.org/cybergeo/26945|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501085510/https://journals.openedition.org/cybergeo/26945|archivedate=1 May 2018|df=}}</ref> and its isolation from the rest of the [[Baltic region]] following the [[2004 enlargement of the European Union|2004 enlargement]] of the [[European Union]].<ref name="sebentsov"/>
In Western media, the region is most often discussed in relation to the deployment of missile systems, initially as a response to the deployment of missile defense systems in Poland and the Czech Republic.<ref name="harding">{{cite news|last1=Harding|first1=Luke|title=Russia threatening new cold war over missile defence|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/apr/11/usa.topstories3|accessdate=3 May 2018|work=the Guardian|date=11 April 2007|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170704131554/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/apr/11/usa.topstories3|archivedate=4 July 2017|df=}}</ref> Russia views the region as a vital element of its ability to project power in the Baltic region.<ref name="michta">{{cite news|last1=Michta|first1=Andrew A.|title=Kaliningrad and the Escalatory Spiral in the Baltics|url=http://carnegieeurope.eu/strategiceurope/66402|accessdate=3 May 2018|work=Carnegie Europe|date=9 December 2016|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171130054710/http://carnegieeurope.eu/strategiceurope/66402|archivedate=30 November 2017|df=}}</ref>
A fringe position also considers the return of the province to [[Germany]] from the [[Russian Federation]], or its independence from both. The former question is mostly hypothetical, as the current [[German government]] has stated that it has no claim to it.{{sfn|Krickus|2002|p=125}}<ref name="moscow">Tétrault-Farber, Gabrielle. "[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/if-russia-gets-crimea-should-germany-get-kaliningrad/496558.html If Russia Gets Crimea, Should Germany Get Kaliningrad?]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6hXtI1jBy Archive]). ''[[The Moscow Times]]''. March 21, 2014.</ref>
==History== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1972-093-65, Flüchtlinge auf Schiff.jpg|thumbnail|[[Refugees from Königsberg]] fleeing to western Germany before the advancing Red Army in 1945]] Kaliningrad, or [[Königsberg]], had been a part of a German state (the [[Teutonic Order]], [[Kingdom of Prussia]], and the [[Imperial Germany|unified Germany]]) for several centuries before the [[Second World War]], and the city was historically a rich German cultural center, being the home of – among others – the German philosopher [[Immanuel Kant]].
The annexation of the Königsberg area of [[East Prussia]] to Russia became a stated war aim of the Soviet Union at [[Tehran Conference]] in December 1943.<ref name="waller">{{cite book|last1=Waller|first1=Michael|last2=Coppieters|first2=Bruno|last3=Malashenko|first3=Alekseĭ Vsevolodovich|title=Conflicting Loyalties and the State in Post-Soviet Russia and Eurasia|date=1998|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780714648828|page=80|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_S9xfdODDUC&pg=PA80|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503193910/https://books.google.com/books?id=J_S9xfdODDUC&pg=PA80|archivedate=2018-05-03|df=}}</ref> In 1945, at the end of [[World War II]], the city was captured by the [[Soviet Union]]. As agreed by the Allies at the [[Potsdam Conference]], northern Prussia, including Königsberg, was annexed by the USSR, which attached it to the [[Russian SFSR]]. In 1946, the city's name was changed to [[Kaliningrad]].
In October 1945, only about 5,000 Soviet civilians lived in the territory.<ref name="malinkin">{{cite web|last1=Malinkin|first1=Mary Elizabeth|title=Building a Soviet City: the Transformation of Königsberg|url=https://www.wilsoncenter.org/article/building-soviet-city-the-transformation-konigsberg|website=Wilson Center|accessdate=2 May 2018|date=8 February 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707061350/https://www.wilsoncenter.org/article/building-soviet-city-the-transformation-konigsberg|archivedate=7 July 2017|df=}}</ref> Between October 1947 and October 1948, about 100,000 [[Flight and expulsion of Germans (1944-50)|Germans were forcibly moved]] to Germany.<ref name="bergerj10">{{cite journal|last1=Berger|first1=Stefan|title=How to be Russian with a Difference? Kaliningrad and its German Past|journal=Geopolitics|date=13 May 2010|volume=15|issue=2|pages=345–366|doi=10.1080/14650040903486967}}</ref> About 400,000 Soviet civilians arrived by 1948.<ref name="malinkin"/> Some moved voluntarily, but as the number of willing settlers proved insufficient, [[collective farms]] were given quotas of how many people they had to send to Kaliningrad.<ref name="malinkin"/> Often they sent the least socially desirable individuals, such as alcoholics and the uneducated.<ref name="malinkin"/>
In the 1950s, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] suggested that the [[Lithuanian SSR]] should annex Kaliningrad Oblast. The offer was refused by the [[Lithuanian Communist Party]] leader [[Antanas Sniečkus]], who did not wish to alter the ethnic composition of his republic.{{sfn|Krickus|2002|p=39}} In the late Soviet era, rumors spread that the Oblast might be converted into a homeland for [[Soviet Germans]].<ref name="diener10">{{cite book|last1=Diener|first1=Alexander C.|last2=Hagen|first2=Joshua|title=Borderlines and Borderlands: Political Oddities at the Edge of the Nation-State|date=2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=9780742568440|page=133|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pci-AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA133|language=en}}</ref>
Kaliningrad Oblast remained part of the Soviet Union until [[USSR dissolution|its dissolution]] in 1991, and since then has been an [[exclave]] of the [[Russia|Russian Federation]]. After the Soviet collapse, some descendants of the expellees and refugees traveled to the city to examine their roots.<ref name="telegraph"/> According to the 2010 Russian Census, 7,349 ethnic Germans live in the Oblast, making up 0.8% of the population.<ref name="2010Census">{{ru-pop-ref|2010Census}}</ref>
In Germany, the status of Kaliningrad and the rights of expellees was a mainstream political issue until the 1960s, when the shifting political discourse increasingly associated similar views with right-wing revisionism.<ref name="bergerj10"/>
According to a ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' article published in 2010, in 1990 the West German government received a message from the Soviet general Geli Batenin, offering to return Kaliningrad.<ref name="ballast"/> The offer was never seriously considered by the Bonn government, who saw [[German reunification|reunification]] with the East as its priority.<ref name="ballast">{{cite news|last1=Wiegrefe|first1=Klaus|title=ZEITGESCHICHTE: Historischer Ballast|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-70569479.html|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=Der Spiegel|date=22 May 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171014130823/http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-70569479.html|archivedate=14 October 2017|df=}}</ref>
In 2001, the EU was alleged to be in talks with Russia to arrange an [[EU association|association]] agreement with the Kaliningrad Oblast, at a time when Russia could not repay £22 billion debt owed to Berlin, which may have given Germany some influence over the territory.<ref name="telegraph">"[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/1318819/Germany-in-secret-talks-with-Russia-to-take-back-Konigsberg.html "Germany in secret talks with Russia to take back Konigsberg] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206041607/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/1318819/Germany-in-secret-talks-with-Russia-to-take-back-Konigsberg.html |date=2018-02-06 }}." ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. January 21, 2001.</ref> Claims of "buying back" Kaliningrad or other "secret deals" were repudiated by both sides.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/kaliningrad-koenigsberg-fuer-eine-hand-voll-euro-a-113527.html|last=Wagner|first=Rudolf|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|language=de|date=22 January 2001|accessdate=2018-03-21|title=Königsberg für eine Hand voll Euro?|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511010948/http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/kaliningrad-koenigsberg-fuer-eine-hand-voll-euro-a-113527.html|archivedate=11 May 2017|df=}}</ref>
Another rumor about a debt-related deal, published by the Russian weekly ''Nash Continent'', alleged that Putin and [[Edmund Stoiber]] had agreed on the gradual return of Kaliningrad in return for waiving the country's $50 billion debt to Germany.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Karabeshkin|first1=Leonid|last2=Wellmann|first2=Christian|title=The Russian Domestic Debate on Kaliningrad: Integrity, Identity and Economy|date=2004|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=9783825879525|page=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=15wH3N8gjE8C&pg=PA20|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501085510/https://books.google.com/books?id=15wH3N8gjE8C&pg=PA20|archivedate=2018-05-01|df=}}</ref>
==Support for irredentism== [[Inesis Feldmanis]], head of the Faculty of History and Philosophy at the [[University of Latvia]], has been quoted saying that the [[Soviet Union]]'s annexation of Kaliningrad is "an error in history".<ref name="moscow"/>
The [[Freistaat Preußen]] Movement, one of the most active offshoots of the [[Reichsbürger]] movement, considers the Russian (and German) government as illegitimate and see themselves as the rightful rulers of the region.<ref name="rhz">{{cite news|title=Reichsbürger: Wie eine „Ministerpräsidentin“ aus der Eifel die Bundesrepublik bekämpft und einen Weltkrieg riskieren will|url=https://www.rhein-zeitung.de/region_artikel,-reichsbuerger-wie-eine-ministerpraesidentin-aus-der-eifel-die-bundesrepublik-bekaempft-und-einen-weltkr-_arid,1610906.html|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=Rhein-Zeitung|date=16 February 2017|language=de|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180325191444/https://www.rhein-zeitung.de/region_artikel,-reichsbuerger-wie-eine-ministerpraesidentin-aus-der-eifel-die-bundesrepublik-bekaempft-und-einen-weltkr-_arid,1610906.html|archivedate=25 March 2018|df=}}</ref> As of 2017, the movement is split into two competing factions, one based in [[Königsfeld, Rhineland-Palatinate]] and the other in Bonn.<ref name="rhz"/>
===In Lithuania=== {{seealso|Lithuania Minor}} Some political groups in [[Lithuania]] claim the parts of Kaliningrad Oblast between the [[Pregolya River|Pregel]] and [[Nemunas river|Nemunas]] Rivers, but they have little influence.{{sfn|Krickus|2002|p=82}} [[Linas Balsys (politician)|Linas Balsys]], a deputy in the Lithuanian parliament, has argued that the status of the exclave should be discussed at international levels.<ref>{{cite news|title=Experts comment on Lithuanian MP’s claims regarding Russia's Kaliningrad|url=http://tass.com/politics/927891|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=TASS|date=30 January 2017|language=ru|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180317113724/http://tass.com/politics/927891|archivedate=17 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
In 1994, the former Lithuanian president [[Vytautas Landsbergis]] called for the separation and '[[decolonization]]' of Kaliningrad from Russia.<ref name="kempton">{{cite book|last1=Kempton|first1=Daniel R.|last2=Clark|first2=Terry D.|title=Unity Or Separation: Center-periphery Relations in the Former Soviet Union|date=2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780275973063|page=145|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vro_ongFiCkC&pg=PA145|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501095203/https://books.google.com/books?id=vro_ongFiCkC&pg=PA145|archivedate=2018-05-01|df=}}</ref> In December 1997, the Lithuanian parliament speaker [[Romualdas Ozolas]] expressed his view that Kaliningrad should become an independent republic.<ref name="vitunic"/>
After the annexation of Crimea in 2014, the political analyst [[Laurynas Kasčiūnas]] called for a revisiting of the Potsdam Agreement.<ref name="lrt">{{cite news|title=Ar Karaliaučiaus statusas turėtų būti peržiūrimas?|url=http://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/pasaulyje/3/65279/ar-karaliauciaus-statusas-turetu-buti-perziurimas|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=Lietuvos Radijas ir Televizija|language=lt|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501095205/https://www.lrt.lt/naujienos/pasaulyje/3/65279/ar-karaliauciaus-statusas-turetu-buti-perziurimas|archivedate=1 May 2018|df=}}</ref> He argued that residents of Kaliningrad would support a referendum to separate from Russia.<ref name="lrt"/> The notion of a Lithuanian claim has been brushed off by Russian media, with the liberal ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'' newspaper dismissing it as a 'geopolitical fantasy'.<ref>{{cite news|title=С легкой претензией на Калининград|url=https://www.novayagazeta.ru/articles/2014/09/26/61321-s-legkoy-pretenziey-na-kaliningrad|accessdate=4 May 2018|work=Новая газета|date=26 September 2014|language=ru-RU|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180504195035/https://www.novayagazeta.ru/articles/2014/09/26/61321-s-legkoy-pretenziey-na-kaliningrad|archivedate=4 May 2018|df=}}</ref>
===German resettlement attempts=== [[File:Munier-Siedlung_Amtshagen_1997.jpg|thumb|The Amtshagen settlement in 1997]] In the 1990s, a far-right group calling itself ''Gesellschaft für Siedlungsförderung in Trakehnen'' attempted to establish a settlement in [[Yasnaya Polyana, Kaliningrad Oblast|Yasnaya Polyana]].<ref name="ihlau">{{cite news|last1=Ihlau|first1=Olaf|title=RUSSLANDDEUTSCHE: „Mich kriegt hier keiner weg“|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-8842841.html|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=Der Spiegel|date=15 December 1997|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170104095948/http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-8842841.html|archivedate=4 January 2017|df=}}</ref> Fundraising by the organization ''Aktion Deutsches Königsberg'' financed the construction of a German-language school and housing in the neighboring village of Amtshagen.<ref name="schwarz02">{{cite news|last1=Schwarz|first1=Moritz|title=Es geht nur mit den Russen|url=https://jungefreiheit.de/service/archiv?artikel=archiv02/212yy56.htm|accessdate=3 May 2018|work=Junge Freiheit|date=17 May 2002|language=de-DE|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503214508/https://jungefreiheit.de/service/archiv?artikel=archiv02%2F212yy56.htm|archivedate=3 May 2018|df=}}</ref> Most of the settlers were [[Russian Germans]] from the Caucasus and Kazakhstan, rather than returnees.<ref name="ihlau95">{{cite news|last1=Ihlau|first1=Olaf|title=Rußlanddeutsche: „Da werden Blasen geschlagen“|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-9180848.html|accessdate=3 May 2018|work=Der Spiegel|date=24 April 1995|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160411172319/http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-9180848.html|archivedate=11 April 2016|df=}}</ref>
Several dilapidated houses were bought and renovated; tractors, trucks, building materials and machinery were imported into the village.<ref name="taz97">{{cite news|last1=Rogalla|first1=Annette|title=Tumbe Germanen wollen Königsberg|url=http://www.taz.de/!1369659/|accessdate=6 May 2018|work=Die Tageszeitung|date=8 December 1997|pages=3|language=de}}</ref> The relatively high salaries attracted newcomers,<ref name="taz97"/> and the ethnic German population rose to about 400 inhabitants.<ref name="strunz06">{{cite book|last1=Strunz|first1=Gunnar|title=Königsberg entdecken: unterwegs zwischen Memel und Haff|date=2006|publisher=Trescher Verlag|isbn=9783897940710|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uZ8Uv3TSRW4C&pg=PA223|language=de}}</ref> The construction of a second settlement in the outskirts of Trakehnen, named ''Agnes-Miegel-Siedlung'', began in 1998.<ref name="schwarz02"/>
Relations with the local Russian administration were initially cordial,<ref name="schwarz02"/> but the activities of the group were suppressed by the Russian government after being publicized by German media.<ref name="bergerj10"/> Dietmar Munier, the initiator of the project, was banned from traveling to Kaliningrad Oblast.<ref name="schwarz02"/> In 2006, he sold his stake in the association to one Alexander Mantai, who turned it into a for-profit concern and evicted the original settlers.<ref name="pferdeland">{{cite news|title=Fata Morgana im Pferdeland|url=http://www.rusdeutsch.eu/Nachrichten/1736|accessdate=3 May 2018|work=Moskauer Deutsche Zeitung|date=10 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503214508/http://www.rusdeutsch.eu/Nachrichten/1736|archivedate=3 May 2018|df=}}</ref> The association was liquidated in 2015 for violating the [[Russian foreign agent law|Russian law on NGOs]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Калининградский суд ликвидировал общественное объединение российских немцев из-за зарубежного финансирования|url=http://interfax-russia.ru/NorthWest/news.asp?id=655422&sec=1672&xid=17259,1500003,15700021,15700124,15700149,15700168,15700173,15700186,15700189,15700201|accessdate=4 May 2018|work=Interfax-Russia.ru|date=24 September 2015|language=ru-RU|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180504195035/http://interfax-russia.ru/NorthWest/news.asp?id=655422&sec=1672&xid=17259,1500003,15700021,15700124,15700149,15700168,15700173,15700186,15700189,15700201|archivedate=4 May 2018|df=}}</ref>
In the 1990s, a group affiliated to [[Manfred Roeder]] collected donations to build housing for ethnic Germans in the village of [[Olchowatka]], east of Kaliningrad.<ref name="spiegel98">{{cite news|title=EXTREMISTEN: Hitlerjunge mit Tränensäcken|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-7870264.html|accessdate=6 May 2018|work=Der Spiegel|date=27 April 1998|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231045439/http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-7870264.html|archivedate=31 December 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Official positions== The German government has indicated no interest in recovering Kaliningrad Oblast.<ref name="berger10">{{cite news|title=Should Kant's home once again be German?|first1=Stefan|last1=Berger|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/jul/31/kalingrad-kant-home-return-german|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=the Guardian|date=31 July 2010|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206041609/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/jul/31/kalingrad-kant-home-return-german|archivedate=6 February 2018|df=}}</ref> The governments of Poland and Lithuania similarly recognize Kaliningrad as part of Russia,<ref name="kempton"/> as does the European Union.<ref name="kortunov">{{cite web|last1=Kortunov|first1=Sergei|title=Kaliningrad: Gateway to Wider Europe|url=http://eng.globalaffairs.ru/number/n_4414|website=Russia in Global Affairs|accessdate=1 May 2018|date=8 February 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017052916/http://eng.globalaffairs.ru/number/n_4414|archivedate=17 October 2014|df=}}</ref> It formally waived all territorial claims to the former [[East Prussia]] as part of the [[Two Plus Four Agreement]] that led to German reunification.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Birckenbach|first1=Hanne-Margret|title=The Kaliningrad Challenge: Options and Recommendations|date=2003|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=9783825866501|page=287|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q4Xjzv0nXCEC&pg=PA287|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501085510/https://books.google.com/books?id=q4Xjzv0nXCEC&pg=PA287|archivedate=2018-05-01|df=}}</ref> In July 2005, the German Chancellor [[Gerhard Schroeder]] declared that "in its heart [the city] will always be called Koenigsberg", but stated that Germany did not have any territorial claim to it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kaliningrad marks key anniversary|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4645447.stm|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=BBC News|date=3 July 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001083409/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4645447.stm|archivedate=1 October 2016|df=}}</ref> According to Ulrich Speck, the prospect of returning Kaliningrad to Germany lacks support in Germany, even among fringe nationalist groups.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Speck|first1=Ulrich|title=Russia and Germany: The Antipodes in the International System|url=http://carnegie.ru/commentary/57311|accessdate=30 April 2018|work=Carnegie Moscow Center|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501085510/http://carnegie.ru/commentary/57311|archivedate=1 May 2018|df=}}</ref> In 2004, the German politician [[Jürgen Klimke]] asked the German federal government about its view on the establishment of a Lithuanian-Russian-Polish [[euroregion]], to be named 'Prussia'. The initiator denied any [[revanchist]] connotations to the proposal.<ref>{{cite news|title=… Russland|url=https://www.tagesspiegel.de/meinung/-russland/557182.html|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=Der Tagesspiegel Online|date=23 October 2004|language=de-DE|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180501095202/https://www.tagesspiegel.de/meinung/-russland/557182.html|archivedate=1 May 2018|df=}}</ref>
After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia's claim to Kaliningrad was not contested by any government,<ref>{{cite news|title=Deplore it, then ignore it|url=https://www.economist.com/node/2206839|accessdate=1 May 2018|work=The Economist|date=20 November 2003|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170726063226/http://www.economist.com/node/2206839|archivedate=26 July 2017|df=}}</ref> though some groups in Lithuania and Poland called for the annexation of the province, or parts of it.<ref name="vitunic">{{cite web|last1=Vitunic|first1=Brian|title=Enclave To Exclave: Kaliningrad Between Russia And The European Union|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/ece/research/intermarium/vol6no1/enclave.pdf|publisher=Columbia University|accessdate=1 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626172125/http://www.columbia.edu/cu/ece/research/intermarium/vol6no1/enclave.pdf|archivedate=26 June 2010|df=}}</ref>
Poland has made no claim to Kaliningrad, and is seen as being unlikely to do so, as it was a net beneficiary of the [[Potsdam Agreement]], which also decided the status of Kaliningrad.{{sfn|Krickus|2002|p=82}}
==See also== * [[Karelian question]] over former Finnish land * [[Landsmannschaft Ostpreußen]], organization for East Prussian refugees/expellees * [[Baltic Republican Party]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * {{cite book|last1=Krickus|first1=Richard J.|title=The Kaliningrad Question|date=2002|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780742517059|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=sDOUZEEnHFUC|ref=harv}}
[[Category:Germany–Russia relations]] [[Category:Irredentism]] [[Category:Politics of Kaliningrad Oblast]] [[Category:Political controversies]]

'''Lemon socialism''' is a pejorative term for a form of [[Nationalization|government intervention]] in which government [[subsidies]] go to weak or failing firms (''lemons''; see [[Lemon law]]), with the effective result that the government (and thus the taxpayer) absorbs part or all of the recipient's losses. The term derives from the conception that in socialism the government may nationalize a company's profits while leaving the company to pay its own losses, while in lemon socialism the company is allowed to keep its profits but its losses are shifted to the taxpayer.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Krugman |first1=Paul |title=The Geithner put |url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/30/the-geithner-put/ |accessdate=27 October 2018 |agency=New York Times |date=30 January 2009}} (Defining lemon socialism as "socialized losses, privatized profits.")</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Rithotz |first1=Barry |title=Greeks Stand Up to 'Lemon Socialism' |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2015-07-06/greeks-stand-up-to-lemon-socialism- |accessdate=27 October 2018 |publisher=Bloomberg |date=6 July 2015}}</ref>
Such payments may be made with the intent of preventing further, systemic damage to what might otherwise be considered a [[Economy|free marketplace]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Newspeak: A Dictionary of Jargon|first=Jonathon|last=Green|pages=142|publisher=Routledge|year=1984|isbn=0-7100-9685-2}}</ref><ref name=shaw>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondchron.org/articles/The_Return_of_Lemon_Socialism_6098.html|title=The Return of “Lemon” Socialism|first=Randy|last=Shaw|publisher=Beyond Chron|date=18 September 2008}}</ref> For example, the [[bailout]] that followed the [[2008 financial crisis]] may be described as lemon socialism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2201245/|title=GOP, RIP? Nearly three decades of Republican dominance may be coming to an end|first=Timothy|last=Noah|authorlink=Timothy Noah|publisher=Slate|date=30 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/09/19/AR2008091903183.html|title=Bailout on Wheels|first=George F.|last=Will|publisher=The Washington Post|date=29 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.pravda.ru/world/asia/24-09-2008/106441-bush_crisis_plan-0|title=The Bush Crisis Plan: Greatest transfer of wealth in world history|publisher=Pravda|date=24 September 2008}}</ref> The pejorative arises from the belief among [[free market]] economists that in a functional free market, failing companies will be replaced by better functioning companies in response to market demand.
The term may also be used to describe government efforts to nationalize companies or industries, in which the government takes over failing companies without taking over healthy companies.<ref name=green74>{{cite news |last1=Green |first1=Mark J. |title=Deciding On Utilities: Public or Private? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/05/26/archives/deciding-on-utilities-public-or-private-con-ed-has-taken-a-step.html |accessdate=27 October 2018 |agency=New York Times |date=26 May 1974}} ("Critics fear that a rush to public ownership may bring a form of “lemon socialism"—where the government, as in England, takes over failing companies, but not healthy ones.")</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Economic Justice and Democracy|first=Robin|last=Hahnel|pages=116|publisher=Routledge|year=2005|isbn=0-415-93344-7}} ("This problem is also referred to as 'lemon socialism': When social democrats were able to nationalize companies, or industries, it was usually because they were in terrible shape. Consequently they often performed badly as public enterprises simply because they were going to perform badly in any case.")</ref> Advocates of free markets may then point to the faltering, nationalized enterprises as examples of how government regulation hurts business.<ref name=shaw/>
== Origin == [[Mark J. Green]] coined the exact phrase in a 1974 article discussing the [[utility company]], [[Con Ed]].<ref name=green74/><ref>{{cite document|title=Lemon credit|last=Krugman|first=Paul|authorlink=Paul Krugman|date=2 February 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/02/02/lemon-credit/|postscript=.}}</ref>
The sentiment was earlier expressed in the adage "[[Socialism for the rich and capitalism for the poor]]", which was in use by the 1960s, though the notion of privatizing profits and socializing losses dates at least to 1834 and [[Andrew Jackson]]'s closing of the [[Second Bank of the United States]].
== Other languages == {{expand section|date=December 2009}} In [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]], lemon socialism is known as "[[:is:Sósíalismi andskotans|Sósíalismi andskotans]]", meaning "the devil's socialism", a term coined by [[Vilmundur Jónsson]] (1889–1971, Iceland's Surgeon General) in the 1930s to criticize alleged [[crony capitalism]] in [[Landsbanki]], which term has gained renewed currency in the debate over the [[2008–2012 Icelandic financial crisis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.hi.is/~gylfason/Oslo%20financial%20crisis%202009.ppt |title=Icelandic banks 2008 in context|author=[http://www3.hi.is/~gylfason/inenglish.htm Thorvaldur Gylfason], grandson of Vilmundur Jónsson}}</ref> Lemon socialism, or more precisely crony capitalism, is also referred to as [[:is:Pilsfaldakapítalismi|Pilsfaldakapítalismi]], meaning "skirt capitalism", ''pilsfaldur'' being the hemline of the skirt; and the term referring to children hiding behind their mothers' skirts after having done something wrong to criticize the alleged lack of transparency in dealings and reluctance to deal with bad consequences by themselves.
== See also == * [[Corporate welfare]] * [[Gresham's law]] * "[[Too big to fail]]"

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Dynamic list}} This is a list of [[scandal]]s or controversies whose names include a "-gate" suffix, by analogy with the [[Watergate scandal]], as well as other incidents to which the suffix has (often facetiously) been applied.<ref>{{citation |url=https://public.oed.com/blog/the-gate-suffix/ |title=Oxford English Dictionary |chapter=-gate, suffix |publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> This list also includes controversies that are widely referred to with a "-gate" suffix, but may be referred to by another more common name (such as the [[New Orleans Saints bounty scandal]]). Use of the "-gate" suffix has spread beyond U.S. English to many other countries and languages.
== Etymology, usage, and history of ''-gate'' ==
The [[suffix]] ''[[wikt:-gate|-gate]]'' derives from the Watergate scandal of the United States in the early 1970s, which resulted in the resignation of [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Richard Nixon]].<ref>"-gate, comb. form." OED Online. Oxford University Press, March 2015. Web. June 8, 2015.</ref> The scandal was named after the [[Watergate complex]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]; the complex itself was named after the "Water Gate" area where [[symphony orchestra]] concerts were staged on the [[Potomac River]] between 1935 and 1965.<ref name=WashingtonPostAnswerManWaterGate>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A60120-2004Dec12.html|title=Answer Man: A Gate to Summers Past|author=John Kelly|work=The Washington Post|date=December 13, 2004|accessdate=September 18, 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jsdEHs1g?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A60120-2004Dec12.html|archivedate=September 18, 2009}}</ref>
The suffix is used to embellish a noun or name to suggest the existence of a [[Conspiracy (criminal)|far-reaching scandal]], particularly in [[politics]] and [[government]]. As a [[CBC News]] column noted in 2001, the term may "suggest unethical behaviour and a [[cover-up]]".<ref>{{cite book |title=The New Partridge Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English: A-I|last=Partridge|first=Eric|page=844|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2006|isbn=978-0-415-25937-8}}</ref>
Such usages have been criticised by commentators as [[cliché]]d and misleading;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-06-16/watergate-scandal-changed-political-landscape/55639974/1|title=Watergate scandal changed the political landscape forever|work=USA Today|date=June 16, 2012|accessdate=September 22, 2012}}</ref> James Stanyer comments that "revelations are given the 'gate' suffix to add a thin veil of credibility, following 'Watergate', but most bear no resemblance to the painstaking investigation of that particular piece of presidential [[corruption]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Stanyer|first=James|title=Modern political communication: mediated politics in uncertain times|page=59|publisher=Polity|year=2007|isbn=978-0-7456-2797-7}}</ref> Stanyer links the widespread use of ''-gate'' to what the sociologist [[John Thompson (sociologist)|John Thompson]] calls "scandal syndrome":
{{quote|[A] self-reproducing and self-reinforcing process, driven on by competitive and combative struggles in the media and political fields and giving rise to more and more scandals which increasingly become the focus of mediated forms of public debate, marginalizing or displacing other issues and producing on occasion a climate of political crisis which can debilitate or even paralyse a government.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=John|authorlink=John Thompson (sociologist)|title=Political scandal: power and visibility in the media age|page=265|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|year=2000|isbn=978-0-7456-2550-8}}</ref>}}
The adoption of ''-gate'' to suggest the existence of a scandal was promoted by [[William Safire]], the conservative ''[[New York Times]]'' columnist and former Nixon administration speechwriter. As early as September 1974 he wrote of "Vietgate", a proposed [[Nixon pardon|pardon of the Watergate criminals]] and [[Vietnam War]] [[draft dodger]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schudson|first=Michael|title=Watergate in American memory: how we remember, forget, and reconstruct the past|page=151|publisher=Basic Books|year=1993|isbn=978-0-465-09083-9}}</ref> Subsequently, he coined numerous ''-gate'' terms, including ''Billygate, Briefingate, Contragate, Deavergate, Debategate, Doublebillingsgate'' (of which he later said "My best [-gate coinage] was the encapsulation of a minor ... scandal as doublebillingsgate"), ''Frankiegate, Franklingate, Genschergate, Housegate, Iraqgate, Koreagate, Lancegate, Maggiegate, Nannygate, Raidergate, Scalpgate, Travelgate, Troopergate'' and ''Whitewatergate''. The ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine suggested that his aim in doing so was "rehabilitating Nixon by relentlessly tarring his successors with the same rhetorical brush – diminished [[guilt by association]]".<ref>{{cite news|title=The Smoking Lexicon|last=Cohen|first=Noam|work=New York Magazine|page=13|date=February 5, 1996}}</ref> Safire himself later said to author [[Eric Alterman]] that he "may have been seeking to minimize the relative importance of the crimes committed by his former boss with this silliness".<ref>{{cite book|title=Sound and fury: the making of the punditocracy|page=79|last=Alterman|first=Eric|year=1999|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-8639-5}}</ref>
The usage has spread into languages other than English; examples of ''-gate'' being used to refer to local political scandals have been reported from [[Argentina]], [[Germany]], [[South Korea]], [[Hungary]], [[Greece]] and the former [[Yugoslavia]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Joseph |first=Brian D. |editor-last1=Spencer |editor-first1=Andrew |editor-last2=Zwicky |editor-first2=Arnold M.|title=The handbook of morphology|page=361|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|chapter=Diachronic Morphology|year=2001|isbn=978-0-631-22694-9}} He cites:
*{{cite journal|last1=Schuhmacher|first1=W. W.|title=More on {{nbh}}Gate|journal=American Speech|date=1989|volume=64|issue=4|page=380|jstor=455733}} (for German) * {{cite journal|last1=Kontra|first1=Miklós|title=Hungarians Turned Gateniks in 1990|journal=American Speech|date=1992|volume=67|issue=2|pages=216–222|jstor=455461|doi=10.2307/455461}} (for Hungarian) * {{cite journal|last1=Joseph|first1=Brian D.|title=Yet More on {{nbh}}Gate Words: A Perspective from Greece|journal=American Speech|date=1992|volume=67|issue=2|pages=222–223|jstor=455462|doi=10.2307/455462}} (for Serbo-Croatian and Greek)</ref>
The use of a suffix in this way is not new. ''-mandering'' has long been used as a suffix by a politician's name in analogy with [[Gerrymandering#Etymology|gerrymandering]] ([[Andrew Johnson#Congressman (1843–1853)|"Henry-mandering" was used in 1852]]). In recent years, the ''-gate'' suffix as a catch-all signifier for scandal has seen some competition from {{nowrap|''-ghazi'',}} as in "Ballghazi" instead of "[[Deflategate]]", or "Bridgeghazi" instead of "[[Fort Lee lane closure scandal|Bridgegate]]". The use of ''-ghazi'' is a play on the [[investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack]], which despite numerous official investigations into the possibility of government cover-ups, has resulted in no criminal charges or major repercussions for the individuals supposedly involved. ''-ghazi'' may be seen as carrying an ironic or self-effacing connotation in its usage, implying that the event described has the appearance and media coverage of a scandal, but does not actually amount to much in a grander sense.<ref>{{cite news|title=DeflateGate ... or Ballghazi? Will the new scandal suffix have staying power|last=Farhi|first=Paul|work=The Washington Post|date=January 27, 2015|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/deflategate--or-ballghazi-will-the-new-scandal-suffix-have-staying-power/2015/01/27/db1c5eac-a571-11e4-a7c2-03d37af98440_story.html}}</ref>

=== Video games === {| class="wikitable" !Name !Year !Description !References |- |[[Driv3rgate]] |2004 |Before the worldwide release of ''[[Driver 3]]'', Atari offered the magazines ''[[PSM3|PSM2]]'' and ''[[Xbox World]]'' early review copies of the game in exchange for positive review scores. This deal was taken by both of them, yet, due to the disappointing nature of the game when it was released, gamers took to forums to complain about the mysterious circumstances related to why both magazines gave positive scores for a heavily berated game. Many then figured out that Atari had paid both, and as a response the comments were systematically wiped by administrators, which gave way to suggestions of a cover up by the publishing house. This controversy would later be referred to as "DRIV3Rgate" and the affair gained a fairly large amount of coverage in the games press and on Internet forums. During this time, Atari hired a guerrilla team to, in desperation, repeatedly make new accounts and post positive threads and comments about the game in an attempt to reduce the controversy. |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/a-question-of-trust|title=A Question of Trust|last1=Fahey|first1=Rob|accessdate=April 12, 2016}}</ref> |- |Gamergate |2014 |See above section [[#Arts and entertainment]] |- |Gerstmanngate |2007 |Refers to the controversy following the November 2007 dismissal of [[Jeff Gerstmann]] from his position as Editorial Director of [[GameSpot]]. Gerstmann had awarded a ''Fair'' rating to the game ''[[Kane & Lynch: Dead Men]]'' at a time when the game was being heavily advertised on GameSpot, which led to accusations from many games journalists of a lack of editorial integrity on the part of GameSpot, who denied that the review had been a part of the reasoning behind the dismissal. However, a subsequent interview with Gerstmann in 2012 countered this statement, with Gerstmann claiming that, although there was more to his firing than any single review, it would not be untrue to say that the Kane & Lynch episode contributed to it. |<ref name="cnetofficial">{{cite web|url=http://www.shacknews.com/onearticle.x/50157|title=CNET Denies 'External Pressure' Caused Gerstmann Termination|date=November 30, 2007|publisher=Shacknews|accessdate=January 28, 2014}}</ref><ref name="onthespot">{{cite_web|url=http://www.gamefront.com/jeff-gerstmann-finally-talks-about-gamespot-firing/|title=Jeff Gerstmann (Finally) Talks About GameSpot Firing|author=Phil Hornshaw|date=March 15, 2012|publisher=[[GameFront]]|accessdate=January 28, 2014}}</ref> |- |Doritogate |2012 |Two initially unconnected events involving video game journalists [[Geoff Keighley]] and Lauren Wainwright are questioned in an article by [[Robert Florence]], triggering a chain of events; {{About|systemic corruption of a government by organised crime syndicates|the 2011 book about Russia|Mafia State (book)}} :''This article refers to a systematic corruption of a government by major organized crime syndicates. For the greater connotation that literally means "rule by thieves", see [[Kleptocracy]].'' {{political corruption sidebar}} The term '''mafia state''' is a political [[buzzword]] to describe a [[Sovereign state|state]] system where the [[government]] is tied with [[organized crime]], including when government officials, [[police]], and/or [[military]] take part in [[Black market|illicit enterprises]].<ref>[http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/137529/moises-naim/mafia-states Mafia States: Organized Crime Takes Office] by Moisés Naím.</ref> The term ''mafia'' is a reference to any organized crime groups strongly connected with the authorities.
According to the critics of the mafia state concept, the term "has now been so used and abused in popularized descriptions of organized criminal activity that it has lost much of its analytic value".<ref name=peter-andreas/>
According to US diplomats, [[Alexander Litvinenko]] coined the phrase Mafia state.<ref name="luhn-harding-guardian">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/04/spain-issues-arrest-warrants-for-russian-officials-close-to-putin | date = 5 November 2015 | access-date = 27 April 2016 | first1 = Alec | last1 = Luhn | first2 = Luke | last2 = Harding | authorlink2 = Luke Harding | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | location = London | title = Spain issues arrest warrants for Russian officials close to Putin}}</ref>
==Particular applications of the concept==
===[[Cosa Nostra]] in Italy and [[Yakuza]] in Japan=== [[File:Giulio Andreotti.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Giulio Andreotti]], seven-time [[Prime Minister of Italy]], was charged with having links to the Mafia]] In a critical review of Moisés Naím's essay in ''[[Foreign Affairs (journal)|Foreign Affairs]]'', Peter Andreas pointed to the long existence of Italian mafia and Japanese [[Yakuza]], writing that there were close relationships between those illicit organisations and respective governments.<ref name=peter-andreas>{{cite web|last=Andreas |first=Peter |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/137692/peter-andreas-moises-naim/measuring-the-mafia-state-menace |title=Measuring the Mafia-State Menace: Are Government-Backed Gangs a Grave New Threat? |publisher=Foreignaffairs.com |date=2012-07-01 |accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref> According to Andreas, these examples speak against incidences of mafia states as a historically new threat.<ref name=peter-andreas/>
In Italy, the actions of the mafia can continue to affect people's lives today. The Italian "Camorra" Mafia network became powerful in the city of [[Naples]] in the 19th Century; although it can trace its origins back to 15th Century Spain and today extending its influence to European countries above Italy as well. The Cosa Nostra and 'Ndrangheta both as well existed in Italy with a confederation of about 150 different groups each with their own organizations and ruling body.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Letizia|first1=Paoli|title=Oxford Handbook of Italian Politics|date=May 2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199669745|pages=670–671}}</ref> Part of the network, known as the "[[Casalesi clan]]" became involved in business in the 1970s and 80s, eventually gaining control of large areas of the local economy "partly by manipulating politicians and intimidating judges". Among the contracts the clan gained was for the disposal of toxic waste, however, much of it was dumped illegally. This dumped toxic waste is thought to be cause of a rise in the number suffering from cancer in towns around Naples. The rise was first noticed two decades ago, and has been calculated that there has been a 40 and 47 per cent increase in cancer in women and men respectively. The Italian Senate is currently investigating the causes of the cancers, with illegal dumping thought to be the likely cause.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-24678624 | work=BBC News | title=The toxic reason a mafia boss became a police informant | date=30 October 2013}}</ref>
===Countries described as Mafia states===
====Republics and territories of the former Yugoslavia==== [[File:Secretary Kerry Puts the Cap Back on His Pen After Signing an Accession Protocol to Continue Montenegro's Admission to NATO in Brussels (27045333901) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Montenegro's president [[Milo Đukanović]] is often described as having strong links to [[Montenegrin mafia]].<ref>"[https://www.occrp.org/personoftheyear/2015/ OCCRP announces 2015 Organized Crime and Corruption ‘Person of the Year’ Award]". [[Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project]].</ref>]] [[Kosovo]], a partially recognised independent state formerly part of Serbia, was called a "mafia state" by Italian MEP [[Pino Arlacchi]] in 2011,<ref name=b92.net>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2011&mm=02&dd=24&nav_id=72906 |title=Kosovo is "mafia state", says Italian MEP |publisher=B92.net |date= |accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref> and also by [[Moisés Naím]] in his 2012 essay "Mafia States" in the ''[[Foreign Affairs (journal)|Foreign Affairs]]''. Naím pointed out that [[Prime Minister of Kosovo]] [[Hashim Thaçi]] is allegedly connected to the heroin trade. Many other crime allegations have been made, and investigated by several countries, against Thaçi.{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}
Naím also labeled [[Montenegro]] as a "mafia state" in the same essay,<ref name=foreignaffairs.com>{{cite web|last=Andreas |first=Peter |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/137692/peter-andreas-moises-naim/measuring-the-mafia-state-menace |title=Measuring the Mafia-State Menace |publisher=Foreignaffairs.com |date=2012-07-01 |accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref> describing it as a hub for [[cigarette smuggling]].<ref name=peter-andreas/>
====Transnistria==== [[Transnistria]], an [[diplomatic recognition|unrecognised]] break-away state from [[Moldova]], has long been described by journalists, researchers, politicians and diplomats as a [[quasistate]] whose economy is dependent on [[contraband]]<ref name="An illegal business ">{{cite web | url=http://www.bne.eu/archive_story.php?id=3467&words[]=contraband&words[]=moldova | title=An illegal business that's smoking | publisher=[[Business New Europe]] | date=2012-04-18 | accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> and [[gunrunning]].<ref name="Ющенко">{{cite web | url=http://korrespondent.net/business/149005-yushchenko-ukraina-nedopoluchaet-iz-za-kontrabandy-iz-pridnestrovya | title=Ющенко: Украина недополучает из-за контрабанды из Приднестровья | publisher=[[Korrespondent]] | date=23 March 2006 | accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Hotbed ">{{cite web | url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2004/jan/18/20040118-103519-5374r/ | title=Hotbed of weapons deals | publisher=[[The Washington Times]] | date=January 18, 2004 | accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Приднестровье самоизолировалось">{{cite news|url=http://www.kommersant.ua/doc/656240 |title=Приднестровье самоизолировалось |work=Kommersant-Ukraine |date=2006-10-03 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |author1=СВИРИДЕНКО, АЛЕКСАНДР |author2=НЕПРЯХИНА, НАТАЛИЯ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102191045/http://www.kommersant.ua/doc/656240 |archivedate=2 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
For instance, in 2002, Moldova's president, [[Vladimir Voronin]], called Transnistria a "residence of international mafia", "smuggling stronghold" and "outpost of [[Islamism|Islamic combatants]]". The allegations were followed by attempts of customs blockade. Reacting to the allegations, [[Russia]]n state-run [[Russia-1 (TV channel)|RTR]] aired an investigative program revealing that Transnistrian firms were conducting industrial-level manufacturing of [[small arms]] purposely for subsequent [[arms trafficking|illegal trafficking]] via the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] port of [[Odessa]]. According to the program, the trade was controlled by and benefited from Transnistria's founder and then-ruler [[Igor Smirnov]].<ref name="ДНЕСТРОВСКИЕ ПОРОГИ">{{cite news | url=http://gazeta.zn.ua/POLITICS/dnestrovskie_porogi.html | script-title=ru:ДНЕСТРОВСКИЕ ПОРОГИ | work=[[Zerkalo Nedeli]] | date=February 8, 2002 | accessdate=2 January 2014 | author=Bulavchenko, Aliona | language=ru}}</ref>
However, more recent investigations and monitoring missions did not prove continuity in [[arms trafficking]] concerns. According to regular reports of the European Border Assistance Mission to Moldova and Ukraine (EUBAM), there have been no signs of significant weapons smuggling from Transnistria.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} During the press-conference on 30 November 2006 head of EUBAM Ferenc Banfi officially stated that organised smuggling of weapons in Transnistria did not exist.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DyWih4cCCc8 Fragment of EUBAM press-conference regarding Mission activities in 2004-2006] Transnistrian Customs Committee Press-Service.</ref> In 2013, Ukrainian Foreign Minister and acting chairman of the OSCE Leonid Kozhara gave an interview to ''El País'' newspaper, commenting on situation in Transnistria and results of work of the EUBAM mission. According to Kozhara, there have been no cases of arms traffic found.<ref>[http://internacional.elpais.com/internacional/2013/06/04/actualidad/1370334170_344660.html Queremos zonas de libre comercio tanto al Este como hacia el Oeste] El Pais. 4 June 2013.</ref>
Some experts from Russia and Transnistria state that allegations of Transnistria being a "mafia state", "black hole of Europe", "heaven for arms trafficking", etc. are a carefully planned defamation campaign paid by the Moldovan government and aimed at producing negative image of Transnistria.<ref>[http://customs-science.net/?p=85 Some aspects of administrative legal regime of customs activities of Transnistria in context of work of international monitoring missions] Customs and Science. 12 May 2011.</ref> Officials from the [[European Union]] and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe ([[OSCE]]), say they have no evidence that the Tiraspol regime has ever trafficked arms or nuclear material.
