{{about|the salute and symbol|the Swedish band|Raised Fist}} {{redirect|Black fist|the film|Black Fist (film)}} [[File:Fist.svg|thumb|150px|right|Painted symbol of the Power Fist]]
The '''raised fist''', or the '''clenched fist''', is a [[symbol]] of [[Social solidarity|solidarity]] and support.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/02/22/every-movement-needs-a-symbol-enter-the-wisconsin-fist-of-solidarity/ |title=Every Movement Needs a Symbol: Enter The Wisconsin Fist of Solidarity |first=Megan |last=Gibson |publisher=Time |date=February 22, 2011 }}{{rs|date=March 2018}}</ref> It is also used as a [[salute]] to express unity, strength, defiance, or [[Resistance movement|resistance]].
==History==
[[File:Spanish War Children (restored).png|thumb|right|Children preparing for evacuation during the [[Spanish Civil War]] (1930s), some giving the Republican salute. The Republicans showed a raised fist whereas the Nationalists gave the [[Roman salute]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Calleja |first1=Eduardo Gonzále |chapter=The symbolism of violence during the Second Republic in Spain, 1931–1936 |title=The Splintering of Spain |chapterurl={{Google books|ypBS6N0aFJgC|page=23|plainurl=yes}} |pages=23–44 |doi=10.1017/CBO9780511497025.005 |editor1-first=Chris |editor1-last=Ealham |editor2-first=Michael |editor2-last=Richards |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-511-49702-5 |quote=The Roman salute characteristic of Italian fascism was first adopted by the PNE and the JONS, later spreading to the Falange and other extreme right groups, before it became the official salute in Franco's Spain. The JAP salute, which consisted of stretching the right arm horizontally to touch the left shoulder enjoyed only relatively little acceptance. The gesture of the raised fist, so widespread among left-wing workers' groups, gave rise to more regimented variations, such as the salute with the fist on one's temple, characteristic of the German ''[[Rotfrontkämpferbund|Rotfront]]'', which was adopted by the republican Popular Army. }}</ref>]]
A raised fist was used as a [[logo]] by the [[Industrial Workers of the World]]<ref>Joyce L. Kornbluh, Solidarity, 1917; Rebel Voices: An IWW Anthology, Charles H. Kerr Publishing, 1998</ref> (IWW) in 1917. However, it was popularised during the [[Spanish Civil War]] of 1936-1939, when it was used by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican faction]] as a greeting, and was known as the "[[Popular Front (Spain)|Popular Front]] salute" or the "[[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] salute". The salute subsequently spread among leftists and anti-fascists across Europe.<ref name=bbc>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17739105 |title=Breivik: What's behind clenched-fist salutes? |last=Kelly |first=Jon |date=17 April 2012 |website=[[bbc.co.uk]] |access-date=7 July 2018}}</ref>
The graphic symbol was popularised in 1948 by [[Taller de Gráfica Popular]], a print shop in [[Mexico]] that used art to advance revolutionary social causes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docspopuli.org/articles/Bancroft/BANC_PIC_2001_206.html|title=Mexican posters on social and educational themes|work=docspopuli.org|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> Its use spread through the United States in the 1960s after artist and activist [[Frank Cieciorka]] produced a simplified version for the [[Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee]]: this version was subsequently used by [[Students for a Democratic Society]] and the [[Black Power movement]].<ref name=aiga>{{cite web |url=https://www.aiga.org/not-your-grandparent-s-clenched-fist |title=Not Your Grandparent’s Clenched Fist |last=Patton |first=Phil |date=10 January 2006 |website=[[American Institute of Graphic Arts]] |access-date=7 July 2018}}</ref>
The raised fist was frequently used in propaganda posters produced during the [[May 1968 events in France|May 1968 revolt in France]], such as ''La Lutte continue'', depicting a factory chimney topped with a clenched fist.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rfi.fr/20180404-culture-france-may-68-posters-show-where-they-were-made-beaux-arts-paris |title=France May 68: the art of revolution |last=Hird |first=Alison |date=4 April 2018 |website=[[rfi.fr]] |access-date=7 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Considine |first1=Liam |date=Autumn 2015 |title=Screen Politics: Pop Art and the Atelier Populaire |url=https://www.tate.org.uk/research/publications/tate-papers/24/screen-politics-pop-art-and-the-atelier-populaire |journal=Tate Papers |issn=1753-9854 |issue=24 |access-date=7 July 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/04/arts/design/may-1968-paris.html |title=Printing a Revolution: The Posters of Paris ’68 |last=Rubin |first=Alissa J. |author-link=Alissa J. Rubin |date=4 May 2018 |website=[[NYTimes.com]] |access-date=4 May 2018}}</ref>
The symbol has been picked up and incorporated around the world by various [[oppression|oppressed]] groups. In 2015 it has emerged in the southeast area of Ukraine among the [[separatists]] battling the Ukraine Kiev government forces, along with the phrase "¡No Pasarán!".<ref>{{cite news |last=Senesi |first=Vauro |date=19 January 2015 |title=Viaggio in Ucraina: al fronte di Lugansk con i ribelli filorussi. Tra fantasmi e ferite |trans-title=Travel to Ukraine: to the Lugansk front with the Russophile rebels. Among phantoms and scars |url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2015/01/19/viaggio-in-ucraina-fronte-lughansk-i-fantasmi-ferite-dei-filorussi/1315641/ |language=Italian |newspaper=Il Fatto Quotidiano |location=Rome |access-date=24 May 2015 }}</ref>
The image gallery shows how a raised fist is used in [[visual communication]]. Combined with another [[graphic design|graphic element]], a raised fist is used to convey [[polysemous]] [[gesture]]s and opposing forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hat4PMRx7lUC&pg=PA28&dq=raised%20fist&hl=en#v=onepage&q=raised%20fist&f=false|title=Elements of Meaning in Gesture|first=Geneviève|last=Calbris|date=1 January 2011|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing|accessdate=16 January 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> Depending on the elements combined, the meaning of the gesture changes in [[Tone (literature)|tone]] and [[intention]]. For example, a [[hammer and sickle]] combined with a raised fist is part of [[communist symbolism]], while the same fist combined with a [[Venus symbol]] represents [[Feminism]], and combined with a [[book]], it represents [[librarian]]s.
A raised-fist icon appears prominently as a feminist symbol on the covers of two major books by [[Robin Morgan]], ''[[Sisterhood is Powerful]]'', published in 1970,<ref>[http://www.robinmorgan.us/robin_morgan_bookDetails.asp?ProductID=9 Author's website], as accessed September 5, 2012.</ref> and ''Sisterhood Is Forever'', in 2003.<ref>[http://www.robinmorgan.us/robin_morgan_bookDetails.asp?ProductID=7 Author's website], as accessed September 5, 2012.</ref> The symbol had been popularised in the feminist movement during the [[Miss America protest]] in 1968 which Morgan co-organised.<ref name=bbc />
A raised fist incorporates the outline of the state of Wisconsin, as designed in 2011, for union protests against the state rescinding collective bargaining.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wisaflcio.typepad.com/wisconsin-state-afl-cio-blog/2011/12/the-blue-fist.html|title=The Story Behind the Blue Fist - Wisconsin State AFL-CIO Blog|work=typepad.com|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref>
<gallery> File:The hand that will rule the world.jpg|''[[Solidarity (U.S. newspaper)|Solidarity]]'' cartoon 1917 File:Civil Liberties in War Times by Max Lerner 1940.jpg|[[Civil liberties]] poster 1940 File:Womanpower logo.jpg|[[Feminism]] File:LibrariansAgainstDRM.svg|[[Librarians]] Against [[Digital rights management|DRM]] File:Otpor-serbian.jpg|[[Otpor!]] File:Flag of Kach and Kahane Chai.svg|[[Kach and Kahane Chai]] File:Piotr Uklanski - Untitled (Fist).jpg|[[Piotr Uklański]], Untitled (Fist) 2008 File:Stand With Wisconsin Raised Fist.pdf|Stand with Wisconsin, 2011 (Wisconsin AFL-CIO) File:Browncoats-Logo.svg|[[Browncoats]] </gallery>
==Logo== [[File:Ekh-faust-foto.png|thumb|90px|right|Stencilled symbol of the [[Autonomism|autonomist]] movement ''Autonome'']] [[Image:Gonzo.svg|left|thumb|90px|The "Gonzo fist"]] The raised fist logo may represent unity or solidarity, generally with oppressed peoples. The black fist, also known as the [[Black Power]] fist is a logo generally associated with [[black nationalism]] and sometimes [[socialism]]. Its most widely known usage is by the [[Black Panther Party]] in the 1960s. A black fist logo was also adopted by the [[northern soul]] music [[subculture]]. The white fist, also known as the Aryan fist or the [[White Supremacy|White Power]] fist is a logo generally associated with [[white nationalism]].
A white fist holding a red rose is used by the [[Socialist International]] and some socialist or [[Social democracy|social democratic]] parties, such as the [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party in France]] and the [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]].<ref name=bbc />
[[Ulster loyalism|Loyalists]] in [[Northern Ireland]] occasionally use a red clenched fist on [[Northern Irish murals|murals]] depicting the [[Red Hand of Ulster]]. However, this is considered rare; the red hand is usually depicted with a flat palm.
[[Irish Republicans]] often have the raised fist as a symbol of resistance against British rule.
The Gonzo fist emblem is characterized by two thumbs and four fingers holding a [[peyote]] button, was originally used in [[Hunter S. Thompson|Hunter S. Thompson's]] 1970 campaign for sheriff of [[Aspen, Colorado]]. It has become a symbol of Thompson and [[gonzo journalism]] as a whole.
The [[Unicode]] character for the raised fist is {{unichar|270A}}.
==Salute== {{Disputed section|date=February 2016}} The raised fist salute consists of raising one arm in the air with a clenched fist. The meaning can vary based on context.
[[Image:Raised Fist at antiwar demo.jpg|thumb|130px|right|[[February 15, 2003 anti-war protest|February 15, 2003]]: A woman raises her fist in solidarity with protestors opposing the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]].]] [[File:John Carlos, Tommie Smith, Peter Norman 1968cr.jpg|thumb|130px|right|Gold medalist [[Tommie Smith]] (center) and bronze medalist [[John Carlos]] (right) showing the raised fist on the podium after the 200 m race at the [[1968 Summer Olympics]]]] Different movements sometimes use different terms to describe the raised fist salute: amongst communists and socialists, it is sometimes called the red salute, whereas amongst some African-American activists, especially in the United States it has been called the [[Black Power]] salute. During the [[Spanish Civil War]], it was sometimes known as the [[anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] salute.
The clenched fist gesture is sometimes thought to have originated in the [[Spanish Civil War]], where the Popular Front salute was at one time the standard salute of Republican forces. A letter from the Spanish Civil War stated: "...the raised fist which greets you in Salud is not just a gesture—it means life and liberty being fought for and a greeting of solidarity with the democratic peoples of the world."<ref>Rolfe, Mary. Letter to Leo Hurwitz and Janey Dudley, 25 November 1938. Reprinted in Cary Nelson and Jefferson Hendricks, eds. "Madrid 1937: Letters of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade from the Spanish Civil War," Routledge: 1996. Reprinted online [http://www.english.uiuc.edu/maps/scw/letters.htm]</ref>
The [[Rotfrontkämpferbund]] [[paramilitary]] organization of [[Communist Party of Germany]] used the salute before [[World War II]] as a probable counter-gesture to the fascist salute.<ref>Korff, Gottfried: "Symbolgeschichte als Sozialgeschichte? Zehn vorläufige Notizen zu den Bild- und Zeichensystemen sozialer Bewegungen in Deutschland", in: Warneken, Bernd Jürgen (Hg.): "Massenmedium Strasse. Zur Kulturgeschichte der Demonstrationen." Frakfurt/Main 1991. S. 27–28. Cited in: Schulte-Rummel, Sven "Die politische Symbolik der Kommunistischen Partei Deutschlands in der Weimarer Republlik" [http://www.hausarbeiten.de/faecher/vorschau/95026.html]. "Im Gegensatz zu den meisten anderen Symbolen der Kommunisten beginnt die Geschichte der geballten Faust in der Ära der Weimarer Republik. Sie war prägendes Symbol bei Straßenaufmärschen, Spiegel der gewaltbereiten Demonstranten, die voller Frust über das System dem Staat die geballte Faust zeigten." Translation: "Unlikely the most of other Communists symbols, the history of Raised fist started in the era of Weimar Republic. It was a definitive symbol of street marches, reflection of the marchers who were ready for violence, who were disappointed by the whole system of the state and showed their clenched fists to it."</ref>
At the [[1968 Summer Olympics]] in [[Mexico City]], medal winners [[John Carlos]] and [[Tommie Smith]] [[1968 Olympics Black Power salute|gave the raised fist salute]] during the American [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]] as a sign of black power, and as a protest on behalf of the Olympic Project for Human Rights. For this, they were banned from further Olympic activities. The event was one of the most overtly political statements<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2094-2393575,00.html | publisher=[[The Sunday Times]] | last=Lewis | first=Richard | date=2006-10-08 | title=Caught in Time: Black Power salute, Mexico, 1968 | accessdate=2008-11-09 | location=London}}</ref> in the history of the modern [[Olympic Games]]. Tommie Smith stated in his autobiography, "Silent Gesture", that the salute was not a Black Power salute, but in fact a [[human rights]] salute.
[[Nelson Mandela]] also used the clenched fist salute upon his release from [[Victor Verster Prison]] in 1990.<ref name=bbc />
A raised White fist is also a popular [[White nationalism#White power|White Power]] symbol.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/16/raised-fist-salute-has-varied-meanings/ |title=Raised-Fist Salute Has Varied Meanings |first=J. David |last=Goodman |date=April 16, 2012 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 12, 2012 }}</ref> The Norwegian right-wing terrorist [[Anders Behring Breivik]] made a clenched-fist salute upon his conviction. Similarly [[Carlos the Jackal]] used the gesture in court, and [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] raised his fist to photographers after his arrest for the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]].<ref name=bbc />
The raised fist is used by officials in Mainland China when being sworn into office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.gov.cn/premier/news/2016/09/18/content_281475445040096.htm|title=State Council holds first swearing-in ceremony to uphold Constitution|work=english.gov.cn|accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref>
Psychologist [[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]] has suggested that the appeal of the salute is that it allows the individual to indicate that they "intend to meet malevolent, massive institutional force with force of (their) own", and that they are bound in struggle with others against common oppression.<ref name=bbc />
==See also== * [[1968 Olympics Black Power salute]] * [[Bellamy salute]] * [[Civil disobedience]] * [[Far-left politics]] * [[Lal Salam]] * [[Protests of 1968]] * [[Roman salute]]

'''Statolatry''', which combines [[idolatry]] with the [[State (polity)|state]], first appeared in [[Giovanni Gentile]]'s ''[[Doctrine of Fascism]]'', published in 1931 under [[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini]]'s name, and was also mentioned in Gramsci's Prison Notebooks (1971) sometime between 1931-1932, while he was imprisoned by Mussolini. The same year, the [[encyclical]] ''[[Non abbiamo bisogno]]'' by [[Pope Pius XI]] criticized [[Italian fascism|Fascist Italy]] as developing "a [[paganism|pagan]] worship of the state" which it called "statolatry".<ref>[http://google.com/search?q=cache:1beJv0ilFMwJ:www.papalencyclicals.net/Pius11/P11FAC.HTM+%22Non+Abbiamo+Bisogno%22+%22statolatry%22&hl=en ''Non abbiamo bisogno'']</ref>
The term '''politiolatry''' was used to describe [[reason of state]] doctrine in the 17th century with similar intent.<ref>Burns, J. H. (ed.) ''The Cambridge History of Political Thought, 1450-1700''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. p. 483.</ref>
== Ludwig von Mises' ''Omnipotent Government'' (1944) ==
The term was also popularized and explained by [[Ludwig von Mises]] in his 1944 work ''[[Omnipotent Government]]''. '''Statolatry''' is literally worship of the State analogous to ''[[idolatry]]'' as worship of idols. It asserts that the glorification and aggrandizement of 'State' or 'Nation' is the object of all legitimate human aspiration at the expense of all else, including personal welfare and independent thought. Expansion of the power and influence of one's State is to be achieved, if necessary, through aggressive [[war]] and [[Colonialism|colonial]] adventures (i.e. [[imperialism]]). It far exceeds the [[patriotism]] of those who recognize the rights of people other than themselves to [[self-determination]], and might best be described as super-patriotism or [[chauvinism]].

page.title: Taxation of the Jews in Europe

revision.text:
'''Taxation of the Jews in Europe''' refers to taxes imposed specifically on [[Jewish]] people in [[Europe]], in addition to the taxes levied on the general population. Special taxation imposed on the Jews by the state or ruler of the territory in which they were living has played an important part in Jewish history.<ref name="Judaica">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/ancienttaxation.html Taxation. Encyclopaedia Judaica.] Reproduced by Jewish Virtual Library.</ref> The abolition of special taxes on the Jews followed their admission to civil rights in France and elsewhere in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries.<ref name="Judaica"/>
== In the Roman Empire == The [[Fiscus Judaicus]] ([[Latin]]: "Jewish tax") or "Temple Tax" was a [[tax]] collecting agency instituted to collect the tax imposed on [[Jewish diaspora#Post-Roman Diaspora|Jews]] in the [[Roman Empire]] after the destruction of the [[Second Temple|Temple of Jerusalem]] in 70 CE in favor of the temple of [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus|Jupiter Capitolinus]] in [[Ancient Rome|Rome]].
The tax was initially imposed by [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]] as one of the [[Anti-Judaism|measures against Jews]] as a result of the [[First Roman-Jewish War]] of 66–73 CE. Vespasian imposed the tax in the aftermath of the [[First Jewish–Roman War|Jewish revolt]] (Josephus ''BJ'' 7. 218; Dio Cassius 65.7.2). The tax was imposed on all Jews throughout the empire, not just on those who took part in the revolt against Rome. The tax was imposed after the [[destruction of the Second Temple]] in 70 CE in place of the levy (or [[Tithe]]) payable by Jews towards the upkeep of the Temple. The amount levied was two [[denarius|denarii]], equivalent to the one-half of a [[shekel]] that observant Jews had previously paid for the upkeep of the Temple of Jerusalem ({{bibleverse||Exodus|30:13|HE}}). The tax was to go instead to the [[Temple of Capitoline Jupiter]], the major center of [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]]. The ''fiscus Iudaicus'' was a humiliation for the Jews.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} In Rome, a special [[procurator (Roman)|procurator]] known as ''procurator ad capitularia Iudaeorum'' was responsible for the collection of the tax.<ref name="Fiscus">"Fiscus Judaicus", ''Encyclopedia Judaica''</ref> Only those who had abandoned Judaism were exempt from paying it.
== In the Holy Roman Empire == The Jewish populations of Europe were politically insecure and could be easily exploited for the levying of heavy taxes in exchange for official protection. The high interest rates charged by Jews became an illimitable source of tax revenue and Jewish wealth was technically easy to gauge because Jews typically stored their assets in the form of cash or promissory notes.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
The Imperial Tax Register of 1241 was the first register to include taxes on the Jews. The total of the taxes on the Jews listed in the Register amounted to 857 silver marks; the total contribution of all the cities together amounted to 4.290 silver marks. These local taxes served wholly or in part to finance town-building. Not all of the contributions reached the central administration. In contrast, it is clear from the Register that the payments made by the Jews reached the Exchequer in their entirety.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 13–14</ref> The taxes on the Jews were first described as the ’’Jewish Tax’’ in 1330.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 18–19</ref>
The Opferfennig (originally Guldenpfennig) tax was introduced in 1342 by Emperor [[Louis IV the Bavarian]], who ordered all Jews above the age of 12 and possessing 20 gulden to pay one gulden annually for protection. This taxation was 1 florin for every Jew and included assets worth more than 20 florins. Widows were not exempted. King Wenceslas removed the taxable minimum but an exemption for Jews dependent on alms was made later by Sigsmund, who himself levied heavy taxation. Sigsmund taxed a third of the value of Jewish properties. It was represented as a coronation tax as part of Sigsmund's attempts to ascend the throne. Isenmann disagrees and believes it was an innovation sprouted by Archchamberlain Konrad von Weinsberg. By 1433-4 the tax collectors were collecting tax worth a half of Jewish properties.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
Emperor [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] later ordered the income of the Opferfennig tax to be delivered to the archbishop of [[Triers]]. This tax was at some places replaced by an overall communal tax.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15120.html OPFERPFENNIG. Encyclopaedia Judaica]. 2008.</ref>
== Leibzoll ==
The ''[[Leibzoll]]'' or ''Judengeleit'' was a special [[tariff|toll]] which Jews had to pay in most of the European states in the [[Middle Ages]] and up to the beginning of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{Cite book| author=Isidore Singer, Cyrus Adler | title=The Jewish Encyclopedia, Vol. 7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzsyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA669| year=1906| publisher=Funk & Wagnalls Company|page=669}}</ref>
== In Hungary == [[Tolerance tax]] (Toleranzgebührer) was a [[tax]] that was levied against [[Jews]] of [[Hungary]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]], beginning in 1747.<ref name="jg">JewishGen. Hungary: Assorted Census Records, 1781-1850 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: The Generations Network, Inc., 2008.</ref>
The tax was based on the German statute that a Jew was obliged to pay a certain tax to be "tolerated".<ref>Wine and thorns in Tokay Valley: Jewish life in Hungary : the history of Abaújszántó, by Zahava Szász Stessel, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 50-51</ref>
== In Poland ==
=== Koło === In 1571 a contract was drafted with regard to the status of the Jews in [[Koło]], in which the city's Christians have undertaken to provide protection to the Jews, in return for which the Jews were required to pay a special annual municipal tax.<ref name="mahler">Mahler, Rafael. [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/kolo/kol008.html "From the near and far past". Some information about the history of the Jews of Koło.]</ref>
In 1729 the Jewish community was required to pay 150 gold coins as an annual poll tax, and in 1738 this sum was increased to 300 gold coins.<ref name="mahler"/>
In 1775 the Polish parliament imposed a special duty on books written in [[Hebrew]] and [[Yiddish]], requiring each book to be stamped by the municipality. Despite heavy penalties imposed on owners of unstamped books, many books were concealed and unstamped.<ref name="mahler"/>
== In Russia == The Russian [[Kosher tax]], known as the ''korobka'', was a tax paid only by Jews for each animal slaughtered in accordance with the [[kashrut]] rules and for each pound of this meat sold.<ref name="ji"/><ref>[http://www.shtetlinks.jewishgen.org/kraziai/history_tax_on_jews.htm Korobka Tax on Kraziai's Jews], Document 49-1-1362 from the Kaunas Archive</ref> It was part of the Russian Jewish "basket tax" or "box tax". Though it was used to refer to a tax on meat or slaughtering, the word ''korobka'' (Russian: коробка) actually means "box" in Russian. The tax came to be called that because Jews paying had to deposit a coin in a box at the kosher slaughterer.<ref name=Diner2001p164>[[Hasia R. Diner|Diner, Hasia R.]] ''Hungering for America: Italian, Irish, and Jewish Foodways in the Age of Migration'', [[Harvard University Press]], 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-674-00605-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zU1WYFWxn74C&pg=PA164 p. 164.]</ref>
According to [[Herman Rosenthal]] and [[Jacob Goodale Lipman]], the tax was "the most burdensome and annoying of the special taxes imposed upon the Jews of Russia by the government".<ref name="ji">[[Herman Rosenthal|Rosenthal, Herman]]; [[Jacob Goodale Lipman|Lipman, J.G.]] [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=394&letter=B "Basket-Tax"], ''[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]''.</ref><ref name="Belovinskiĭ2003p357">Leonid Vasilʹevich Belovinskiĭ. ''Энциклопедический словарь российской жизни и истории: XVIII-начало XX в'', Olma Media Group, 2003, {{ISBN|978-5-224-04008-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=4W5sUATx57MC&pg=PA357 p. 357.]</ref><ref>[[Simon Dubnow|Dubnow, Simon]]; [[Israel Friedlander|Friedlaender, Israel]]. ''History of the Jews in Russia and Poland'', Avotaynu Inc, 2000 {{ISBN|978-1-886223-11-0}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vL60sEf7OPoC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227 p. 227.]</ref> The burden of taxes, and the ''korobka'' in particular, was one of the factors which drove many Jews to abandon the towns and settle in villages or on noblemen estates.<ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica (1971): History, vol. 8, 734</ref>
==In Galicia== Between 1777 and 1784, the Jews of [[Horodenka]], a region on the southeast corner of [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Galicia]], paid a number of special taxes, including the "protection and [[tolerance tax]]", and the "property and occupation tax". In 1784, the property and occupation tax was replaced with the kosher meat tax.<ref>Gelber, N. M. ''The History of the Jews of Horodenka'', p. 86.</ref>
==In Moldavia== In 1741, Moldavian prince [[Grigore II Ghica|Grigore Ghica]] confirmed the obligation of each Jew to pay the crupca, an indirect tax on kosher meat similar to the Russian ''korobka''.<ref>[http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/printarticle.aspx?id=925 Iaşi, by Lucian-Zeev Herşcovici ]</ref>
== In Altona and Hamburg == During the period 1641–1842, the [[Jews]] of [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] (then a town close to Hamburg) paid specifically Jewish taxes as well as the same taxes as other residents of Altona. The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents.
In 1640 the Danish King [[Christian IV]] acquired part of the [[Holstein-Pinneberg|County of Pinneberg]] including Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 25–26</ref> Altona was subsequently granted the rights and status of a town on 23 August 1664.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 53–54</ref>
=== Jews in Hamburg ===
The community was founded principally by Portuguese merchants and was known as the [[Portuguese Jewish community in Hamburg|Portuguese-Jewish Community]], although many of its members were of Spanish-Jewish descent.
These [[Sephardic Jews]], who initially pretended to be persecuted [[Catholic]]s, first came to [[Hamburg]] at the end of the 16th century. They were mostly Portuguese- or Spanish-speaking merchants. In 1621, when the armistice between [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] came to an end, many of the Portuguese Jews moved to Hamburg. They were made welcome, even after the actual situation had become clear; however they were not permitted to establish a cemetery within the city walls. Thanks to the linguistic skills of the Sephardim and their contacts among their co-religionaries they controlled a large sector of the German market in provisions. The Sephardim differed culturally and socially from the Jews who came to Altona, and subsequently also to Hamburg, from the east. These were [[Yiddish Language]] speaking [[Ashkenazim]]. The permanent settlement of the Ashkenazim was opposed by both the [[Senate of Hamburg]] (town council) and the citizens, supported by the Sephardim, who did not wish to see the establishment of a second community in Hamburg. As servants, referred to as tudescos, the Ashkenazi Jews were, de facto, under the protection of the Sephardic Jews.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 91–94</ref>
=== Jews in Altona ===
On 1 August 1641 the Danish king had formally granted the Ashkenazi Jews the privilege of having in Altona, as hitherto, a cemetery and a synagogue, thus providing the basis for the existence of a Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 111</ref> Subsequently, the Danish kings promised the Jews personal security, the freedom to practice trade and religious liberties. Some of the Jews living in Hamburg therefore tried to secure the legal protection of the Danish crown in case of any attempt to expel them. In Altona the conditions of residence were favorable, in Hamburg the conditions for trading. These were the reasons for the genesis of the Altona community of Ashkenazi Jews from Hamburg and Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 91</ref> Thanks to immigration from the east, Altona became a center of research and scholarship in Jewish teaching, attracting hundreds of students. The officially recognized [[Beth din|Jewish court of justice]] had a reputation as one of the most distinguished in the whole Jewish world.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 243–244</ref> The Jews did not acquire these privileges freely, but in return for the payment of taxes.
=== Levies on Jews ===
From 1584 to 1639, as in the Middle Ages, the Jews of Altona paid taxes specific to the Jews, but no further taxes. Each Jewish family was required to pay 6 [[rixdollar|Reichstaler]] per year. Under Danish rule this changed: the Jews continued to pay the specifically Jewish taxes plus the same taxes as all other residents.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135</ref> From 1641 every Jewish family was required to pay 5 Reichstaler in Jewish taxes; in the year when Altona became a town the contribution rose to 6 Reichstaler.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135, pp. 180–181</ref> With the ordinance of 1641 the Danish king had permitted the Jews [[shechita]]. This privilege too was not cost-free. For the years 1667–1669 we have records of taxes paid by Jewish butchers. According to these the rates were 1 Mark and 8 Schillinge for an ox, 4 Schillinge for a calf and 2 Schillinge for a lamb. These taxes were twice as high as those paid by Christian butchers.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 153, pp. 168–169</ref> From 1681 Individual taxes on the Jews (6 Reichstaler plus the payments made by the Jewish butchers), were replaced by lump-sum payments by the Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 156</ref>
From the year 1712 onwards it is possible to calculate the amount of the lump-sum payments made by the Jews. During the period 1712–1818 this amounted to 6 Reichstaler for each Jewish family; 6 Reichstaler was the level that had already been set in 1584. Assuming that a Jewish family consisted of approximately 6 persons, 6 Reichstaler corresponded to 1 Reichstaler for each individual Jew. On top of this 1 Reichstaler, also paid by the other residents, had to be paid.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 265-266. Meaningful conversion of the face-value can be made for this period since, unlike the paper money of Copenhagen, the silver currency of Altona was stable, p. 50</ref> The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents. The influence of this on business practice constituted an obstacle to the granting of civil rights. In the year 1818 the Jewish Elders declared to the community of Altona that they could not, ’’on the one hand, levy specifically Jewish taxes on the members of their community and, on the other hand, encourage our co-religionaries, especially the younger ones, to pursue useful activity. In short: so to improve our condition that we might not seem unworthy to acquire civil rights. The extension – against our wishes - of the taxes on the Jews would be incompatible with the granting of civil rights.’’<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 239</ref> This marks the beginning of the struggle of the Jewish community for emancipation. The Jewish community secured the abolition of taxes on the Jews in the year 1842.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 199</ref>

page.title: The Chinese State in Ming Society

revision.text:
{{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Chinese State in Ming Society | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Chinese State in Ming Society.jpg | caption = Front cover of ''The Chinese State in Ming Society'' | author = [[Timothy Brook]] | cover_artist = | country = [[London]], United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = History | publisher = ''[[Routledge]]'' (Critical Asian Scholarship series) | release_date = 17 December 2004 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) | pages = 272 | isbn = 0-415-34506-5 | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Chinese State in Ming Society''''' is a history book which investigates the role of the [[Government|state]] in China in the [[Ming dynasty]] (from 1368 to 1644 in the [[Late Imperial China|late Imperial Chinese era]]); the interface between the state and [[society]], and the effect of the state on ordinary people.<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies">{{cite journal | last = Soulliere | first = Ellen | authorlink = | title = Timothy Brook, The Chinese State in Ming Society | journal = [[New Zealand Journal of Asian Studies]] | volume = 8 | issue = 1 | pages = 168–171 | publisher = New Zealand Asian Studies Society | date = June 2006 | url = http://www.nzasia.org.nz/downloads/NZJAS-June06/8.pdf | format = PDF | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2010-01-28}}</ref><ref name="RoutledgeBlurb">{{cite web | last = Staff | first = | authorlink = | title = The Chinese State in Ming Society: About the Book | publisher = [[Routledge]] | year = 2004 | url = http://www.routledge.com/books/The-Chinese-State-in-Ming-Society-ISBN 978-0-415-34507-1 | accessdate = 2010-01-29}}</ref>
The book is written by [[Timothy Brook]], a distinguished<ref name="WashingtonPostDirda">{{cite web | last = Dirda | first = Michael | title = Painting the World: How a hunger for tea and tobacco created global trade. | work = [[Washington Post]] | date = 27 January 2008 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/24/AR2008012402715.html | accessdate = 2010-01-22}}</ref> Canadian [[historian]] who specializes in the study of China ([[Sinology]]).<ref name="ObserverConrad">{{cite web | authorlink = Peter Conrad (academic) | last = Conrad | first = Peter | title = A time when every picture told a story | work= [[The Observer]] | date = 29 June 2008 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/jun/29/review.features1 | accessdate = 2010-01-22}}</ref>
==Synopsis== ''The Chinese State in Ming Society '' is set in the Ming dynasty, an era in which there was much "[[Commerce|commercial]] expansion and [[Culture|cultural]] [[innovation]]".<ref name="RoutledgeBlurb"/> The book is an "account of events and issues that engaged the members of local [[elite]]s in [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] society and of the interface between these elites and the state,"<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/> and the impact of the state on ordinary people in areas such as [[education]], [[Judiciary|justice]], the [[military]] and [[taxation]].<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/>
The book consists of a reworking of eight "heavily illustrated" essays which Brook has written and published separately over the years, and is divided into four main sections (parts I to IV) with two of these essays to each part of the book.<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/><ref name="RoutledgeBlurb"/> The parts are named "Space", "Fields", "Books" and "[[Monastery|Monasteries]]", each of which "represent important areas of intersection between the Ming state and society."<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/><ref name="RoutledgeBlurb"/>
Brook argues that the model of [[despotism|despotic government]] fails to account for the complex interactions between individuals, groups, communities, society and state in this period.<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/> Instead he proposes that by 1500 the Chinese had a remarkably developed system of [[Government|governance]], surpassing that of the European [[Monarchy|monarchs]] of the time, and that the developments were not the result of the isolated actions of the state, but rather of a complex interface and interaction, including local representatives of the state such as [[magistrate]]s and local networks of the elite [[Social class|class]] of [[gentry]].<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/> According to Ellen Soulliere in her review, Brook argues that "society had the [enduring] ability to constrain, limit and sometimes redirect the [[authority]] of the state, without challenging its most basic claim to be the source of all legitimate authority."<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/>
==Reception== {{Expand section|date=January 2010}} Writing in the ''[[New Zealand Journal of Asian Studies]]'', Ellen Soulliere describes the book as a "detailed", "succinct" and "compelling" account.<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/> In conclusion, she states that "All in all, this is a fascinating and very valuable book that addresses major themes in [[History of China|Chinese history]] while greatly expanding our detailed knowledge of the issues that engaged people at the level of their local communities. It illuminates the [[Group conflict|conflicts]] and [[Controversy|controversies]] that kept the state and society in a state of dynamic tension throughout the Ming period and beyond."<ref name="NewZealandJournalOfAsianStudies"/>
